name: Simple Present

examples: She goes to school every day.
The sun rises in the east.
She does not go to school every day.
The sun does not rise in the west.
Does she go to school every day?
Does the sun rise in the east?

usage: Expresses habits or repeated actions.
States facts or general truths.
Describes schedules or timetables.
Expresses feelings, thoughts, or states.

name: Present Continuous

examples: I am reading a book now.
They are playing football.
I am not reading a book now.
They are not playing football.
Are you reading a book now?
Are they playing football?

usage: Describes actions happening at the moment of speaking.
Expresses future plans or arrangements.
Describes temporary actions or situations.
Expresses changing or developing situations.

name: Present Perfect

examples: I have seen that movie twice.
She has lived here for five years.
I have not seen that movie.
She has not lived here long.
Have you seen that movie?
Has she lived here for five years?

usage: Describes actions completed in the past with present relevance.
Expresses experiences or achievements.
Describes actions that started in the past and continue to the present.
Describes actions that have occurred multiple times in the past.

name: Present Perfect Continuous

examples: I have been studying English for two hours.
It has been raining since morning.
I have not been studying for long.
It has not been raining much.
Have you been studying English for two hours?
Has it been raining since morning?

usage: Describes actions that started in the past and continue to the present.
Emphasizes the duration or continuity of an action.
Describes actions that have recently stopped.

name: Simple Past

examples: I visited Paris last year.
She walked to school yesterday.
I did not visit Paris last year.
She did not walk to school yesterday.
Did you visit Paris last year?
Did she walk to school yesterday?

usage: Describes completed actions in the past.
Expresses past habits or routines.
Describes a series of completed actions in the past.

name: Past Continuous

examples: I was watching TV at 8 p.m. yesterday.
They were playing football when it started raining.
I was not watching TV at 8 p.m. yesterday.
They were not playing football when it started raining.
Were you watching TV at 8 p.m. yesterday?
Were they playing football when it started raining?

usage: Describes actions that were ongoing at a specific time in the past.
Expresses two actions happening simultaneously in the past.
Describes an action that was interrupted in the past.

name: Past Perfect

examples: I had finished my homework before I went to bed.
She had already eaten when I invited her to dinner.
I had not finished my homework before I went to bed.
She had not eaten when I invited her to dinner.
Had you finished your homework before you went to bed?
Had she eaten when you invited her to dinner?

usage: Describes actions completed before another action in the past.
Expresses actions completed before a specific time in the past.

name: Past Perfect Continuous

examples: I had been waiting for two hours when she finally arrived.
They had been playing football before it started raining.
I had not been waiting long when she arrived.
They had not been playing football for long before it started raining.
Had you been waiting for two hours when she arrived?
Had they been playing football before it started raining?

usage: Describes actions that were ongoing before another action in the past.
Emphasizes the duration of an action before a specific point in the past.

name: Simple Future

examples: I will call you tomorrow.
It will rain later.
I will not call you tomorrow.
It will not rain later.
Will you call me tomorrow?
Will it rain later?

usage: Describes actions that will happen in the future.
Expresses predictions, promises, or instant decisions.

name: Future Continuous

examples: I will be sleeping at midnight.
They will be traveling next week.
I will not be sleeping at midnight.
They will not be traveling next week.
Will you be sleeping at midnight?
Will they be traveling next week?

usage: Describes actions that will be ongoing at a specific time in the future.
Expresses actions that will occur over a period in the future.

name: Future Perfect

examples: I will have finished my project by next Monday.
She will have graduated by next year.
I will not have finished my project by next Monday.
She will not have graduated by next year.
Will you have finished your project by next Monday?
Will she have graduated by next year?

usage: Describes actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
Expresses actions that will be completed before another future action.

name: Future Perfect Continuous

examples: I will have been working here for ten years by next month.
She will have been waiting for two hours by the time the bus arrives.

negative.formula: S + will + not + have + been + V-ing
examples: I will not have been working here for ten years by next month.
She will not have been waiting for two hours by the time the bus arrives.
Will you have been working here for ten years by next month?
Will she have been waiting for two hours by the time the bus arrives?

usage: Describes actions that will have been ongoing up to a specific point in the future.
Emphasizes the duration of an action up to a future point.
